hints_html: What do you notice about the interval of integration? How can you use this to your advantage?
hints_latex:
What do you notice about the interval of integration? How can you use
this to your advantage?
hints_raw: What do you notice about the interval of integration? How can you use this to your advantage?
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Since \(x^{1/3}\) is an odd function and \(\cos(x)\) is an even function, we know that their product is an odd function. More directly, notice that if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = x^{1/3}\cos(x)\, dx\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(-x) = (-x)^{1/3}\cos(-x) = -x^{1/3}\cos(x) = -f(x)\end{aligned}\]

and so the function is odd. As the interval of integration is symmetric, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-2012}^{2012}x^{1/3}\cos(x)\, dx = 0.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Since <math> x^{1/3} </math> is an odd function and <math> \cos(x) </math> is an even function, we know that their product is an odd function. More directly, notice that if

:<math>
\displaystyle f(x) = x^{1/3}\cos(x)\, dx
</math>

then

:<math>
\displaystyle f(-x) = (-x)^{1/3}\cos(-x) = -x^{1/3}\cos(x) = -f(x)
</math>

and so the function is odd. As the interval of integration is symmetric, we have that

:<math>
\int_{-2012}^{2012}x^{1/3}\cos(x)\, dx = 0.
</math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Question. Show all your work, simplify your answer as much as possible.

Evaluate

\(\int_{-2012}^{2012}x^{1/3}\cos(x)\, dx\)

as much as possible.

$\int_{-2012}^{2012}x^{1/3}\cos(x)\, dx$
